speaker: Derek Roland Clark,
english:
Derek Roland Clark, on behalf of the IND/DEM Group . – Mr President, the report on employment policies is over-laden with key phrases, the tone for which is set very early on: legislation, EC monitors and enforcement. Then we have got the special importance of younger and older workers; then the EU without barriers – remove them, it says – with clear and measurable priorities; review the guidelines every three years, but Parliament must be more active between times; examine Member States’ national reform programmes. Well, let us do that. The French took a 35-hour working week, not a 48-hour week. But when the Working Time Directive was given flesh last year, many of their workers protested at EU interference.
Port workers protested earlier this year at more EU interference. French cities are now under siege due to new youth employment policies. Who is going to tell Mr Chirac or Mr de Villepin that they are wrong, they are not conforming to guidelines? Of course you will not. The French will govern themselves, as all of us should do, as grown-up democracies. But most sinister of all in this report is Guideline 19: continual review of incentives and disincentives resulting from the tax and benefits systems. Already a colleague has spoken this morning of a single fiscal policy. Is this the start of EU harmonisation of tax policy across the Union – something they said would never happen? Ladies and gentlemen, your tax systems are under threat. You have been warned!

agenda_item: Guidelines for Member States’ employment policies – Broad economic policy guidelines for 2006 (debate)
summary_english:
{
"headline": "EU Employment Guidelines Threaten National Sovereignty and Tax Systems Through Excessive Interference",
"issueSum": "The speaker raises concerns about the EU's employment policy guidelines, highlighting excessive EU legislation, monitoring and enforcement mechanisms. Key issues include EU interference in national employment policies (citing French examples of 35-hour work week protests and port worker protests), youth employment policies causing civil unrest in French cities, and particularly Guideline 19 which calls for continual review of tax and benefits systems as a potential threat to national tax sovereignty.",
"positionSum": "The speaker strongly opposes the EU employment guidelines, viewing them as excessive interference in national sovereignty. He advocates for member states governing themselves as 'grown-up democracies' without EU interference. He is particularly concerned about potential EU harmonisation of tax policy, warning that national tax systems are under threat.",
"argSum": "The speaker argues that EU interference is counterproductive, citing examples where French workers protested against EU directives like the Working Time Directive and port services directive. He contends that national governments should have sovereignty over their own employment and tax policies, and warns that Guideline 19 represents the beginning of EU tax harmonisation despite previous assurances this would never happen.",
"propSum": "The speaker does not propose specific policy actions but advocates for member states to govern themselves independently without EU interference in employment and tax policies. He warns against the implementation of Guideline 19 and calls for resistance to EU harmonisation of tax policy.",
"quotes": ["The French will govern themselves, as all of us should do, as grown-up democracies", "Already a colleague has spoken this morning of a single fiscal policy. Is this the start of EU harmonisation of tax policy across the Union – something they said would never happen?", "Ladies and gentlemen, your tax systems are under threat. You have been warned!"]
}
